abstract.p: New Jersey Devils defeat Montreal Canadiens, 8-4; photo (M)

block.p: Amid a laser light show, the sellout crowd roared with delight as the Stanley Cup stood at center ice.

A few minutes later, the Stanley Cup banner was raised to the rafters of the Continental Arena. But the loudest cheer on a night of celebration for the Devils was the resounding chant of ''We Want Arnott.''
Amid a laser light show, the sellout crowd roared with delight as the Stanley Cup stood at center ice.

A few minutes later, the Stanley Cup banner was raised to the rafters of the Continental Arena. But the loudest cheer on a night of celebration for the Devils was the resounding chant of ''We Want Arnott.''
Jason Arnott, the unrestricted free agent who scored the Stanley Cup-clinching goal in overtime against Dallas last spring, remains unsigned.
And Scott Niedermayer, the team's leading point-scorer for the past five seasons, was also not on the ice for the Devils' 8-4 trouncing of the Montreal Canadiens in the season opener.
For one night, at least, the Devils did not miss Arnott or Niedermayer as they remained undefeated in their last 10 home openers (8-0-2).

They built a 2-0 lead on goals by Bobby Holik and Sergei Nemchinov in the first seven minutes, but Montreal's Brian Savage and the rookie Xavier Delisle countered and the first period ended deadlocked.

The Devils scored three goals in a span of 3 minutes 18 seconds in the second period to put the game out of reach. Petr Sykora started the outburst 1:41 into the period and Alexander Mogliny and Colin White completed it before the period was five minutes old.

Saku Koivu pulled the Canadiens to 5-3. But Mogilny scored his second of the night at 3:57 of the third and Turner Stevenson added a goal at 5:04 to bury the Canadiens, who missed the playoffs the last two seasons.
Oleg Petrov added a goal for the Canadiens at 11:23 before Steve Kelly closed out the scoring for the Devils at 16:51.
Tonight was a night to savor for former Devils owner John McMullen. The 82-year-old McMullen, who sold the team to YankeeNets, raised the banner with his family and Scott Stevens, the captain.
''He's been like a father to me,'' said Ken Daneyko, the 18-year veteran defenseman.
Stevens, who won the Conn Smythe trophy as the most valuable player of the playoffs, said, ''It's like an athlete in the Olympics winning a gold medal and they play the national anthem.''
Martin Brodeur, who was dominant against Dallas last spring and had 26 saves tonight, said the raising of the banner made the Devils' championship official.

''It's nice to see the banner in your building hanging there forever -- unless we move into a new building,'' Brodeur said with a laugh, alluding to the possibility of the team moving to Newark. ''You can look at it and it will bring back memories.''
Brodeur didn't have one of his better nights, but the Devils provided enough firepower for the victory.
''There was a lot of emotion and you always worry about wide-open games like this,'' Devils Coach Larry Robinson said. ''You tell the guys to focus, but it was so emotional I lost focus myself.''
SLAP SHOTS

The Devils scratched forwards JIM McKENZIE and ED WARD, both newcomers, and defenseman SASCHA GOC. . . . The three quick goals early in the second period signaled the end for Montreal goalie JEFF HACKETT. He allowed five goals on 13 shots and was replaced by MATHIEU GARON.
